New Records: Anthony Volpe made history as the first player to record four-plus RBIs and two stolen bases in a World Series game.
Freddie Freeman became the first player to hit a home run in each of the first four games of a single World Series.
Key Match Events: Freddie Freeman hit a home run to open a 2-0 Dodgers lead in the first inning.
Anthony Volpe hit a grand slam in the bottom of the third inning to give the Yankees a 5-2 lead.
Gleyber Torres hit a three-run homer in the bottom of the eighth inning to extend New York's lead to 10-4.
Aaron Judge recorded his first RBI of the World Series in the bottom of the eighth inning.
Austin Wells hit a solo home run in the bottom of the sixth inning.
Tim Mayza closed out the Dodgers in the top of the ninth inning, retiring the batters in order.
Pre-Game Insights: Dodgers manager Dave Roberts emphasized the importance of focusing on getting 27 outs in Game 4.
Yankees manager Aaron Boone made tweaks to the starting lineup, including moving Jazz Chisholm Jr. up the order and starting Austin Wells.
Post-Match Reflections: Yankees' Jazz Chisholm Jr. expressed the team's desire to make history by coming back from a 3-0 deficit.
Austin Wells discussed his mindset after struggling in the postseason, saying he approached the game with a 'screw it' mentality.
Miscellaneous Highlights: Ashanti performed the national anthem before Game 4.
Paul O'Neill threw the ceremonial first pitch for Game 4.
The World Series Game 3 averaged 13.64 million viewers, beating 'Monday Night Football' in viewership.
